image.altText: A gas platform in the Timor Sea.

props.synopsis: Santos has been granted permission to resume laying an underwater pipeline for its Barossa gas project, north of Darwin, after winning a legal battle against a group of Tiwi Islands elders.

title.children: Santos wins legal battle against Tiwi Islands elders over $5.7b Barossa gas pipeline

image.altText: People mill past Australian Open signage at the beginning of the tournament.

props.synopsis: Freedom of Information documents reveal Victorian taxpayers made two multi-million-dollar support payments to Tennis Australia to cover Australian Open COVID-19 costs.

title.children: Victorian government defends value of Australian Open after documents reveal $100m Tennis Australia bailout

image.altText: Dr Ash Gordon wears a white collared shirt and blue blazer and smiles in front of a cream brick wall.

props.synopsis: Ash Gordon, a doctor working in Melbourne's east, has been named as the man found dead on a Doncaster street after a weekend home invasion.

title.children: Tributes for 'well loved, respected' doctor who died after home invasion in Melbourne's east

image.altText: A woman in hi-vis smiles at the camera in front of a school building

props.synopsis: Tahlia Quinlivan is vastly outnumbered by men in her workplace, but that only spurs her drive to succeed. She says women in her field are smashing down barriers, creating more diverse and compassionate workplaces.

title.children: As more women like Tahlia train for jobs traditionally done by men, workplaces are changing for the better

image.altText: Fireworks over the city of Copenhaguen where many buildings are lit up in the dark

props.synopsis: Near-freezing temperatures have not stopped the Danish from welcoming their new king, Frederik X, and his Australian-born wife, Queen Mary. Here are some of the best photos of the Nordic nation's first royal succession in half a century.

title.children: Tears, cheers and Australian flags as Denmark welcomes new king and queen

image.altText: Jabiru sign.jpg

props.synopsis: A boy, aged nine, has been bitten near Jabiru, the biggest town in Kakadu, sustaining a number of puncture wounds.

title.children: Boy critically injured in Kakadu crocodile attack

image.altText: an aerial shot of a boat ramp and small jetty

props.synopsis: Police have revealed a man who died on the Gippsland coast last week, one of three who drowned in separate incidents, was a freediver who had lost his fins.

title.children: Freediver lost fins before drowning during tragic day off the coast of Victoria, police say

props.synopsis: Beach safety expert Professor Rob Brander explains what flash rips are and how swimmers can stay safe if they are caught in one.

title.children: What to do if you get caught in a 'tricky and unpredictable' flash rip

image.altText: A young man in a black suit and black hat walks past half-constructed homes on an arid hill

props.synopsis: The federal government has denounced Israeli settler violence and illegal settlements in the occupied West Bank, but Labor MP Julian Hill says "stern words" are not enough and the government should move to block any funding that helps establish settlements.

title.children: Labor backbencher calls for ban on Australians funding illegal Israeli settlements

image.altText: A man crying while his family stands next to him

props.synopsis: After his mother put in her two weeks notice on New Year's Eve, the newly minted King Frederik X has been proclaimed monarch of Denmark. Here's everything that happened while you were asleep.

title.children: Denmark's King Frederik wanted a low-key accession. But one thing he saw brought him to tears

image.altText: A yellow road closed sign stands on the roadway in front of a police car that is blocking the highway.

props.synopsis: An 11-year-old boy and 26-year-old woman are dead after a car hit a tree and burst into flames near Echuca.

title.children: 11yo boy, woman dead after car hits tree in Victoria's north

image.altText: Dash cam still showing person holding item in tray of ute on highway.

props.synopsis: Employees of the Big Bash League cricket team Hobart Hurricanes are caught out after dash cam vision shows a team-branded ute travelling on a major highway with a person riding in the tray holding a large box.

title.children: Dash cam catches out Hobart Hurricanes employees ute tray ride on highway

image.altText: A man in an orange shirt, facing away, sits in a car with the doors open.

props.synopsis: About 70,000 people live in Australia unlawfully. To avoid getting caught, Shan had to go underground — a path he warns no-one should walk.

title.children: When police pulled Shan over, he knew his secret life had just come undone

image.altText: America Ferrera in a born evening gown clutching an award and Margot Robbie in a red evening gown, both smiling

props.synopsis: While Barbie didn't go home with all the awards it was nominated for at the 29th annual Critics Choice Awards, it was a good night for the Margot Robbie-produced movie, with America Ferrera being recognised and host Chelsea Handler declaring this the "year of the woman".

title.children: Barbie shines at the Critics Choice Awards

image.altText: A man plays a shot during a tennis match

props.synopsis: Alexei Popyrin has triumphed against fellow Australian Marc Polmans to set up a second round showdown with world number one Novak Djokovic. Follow live.

title.children: Alexei Popyrin wins all-Aussie showdown to set up clash with Novak Djokovic

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Alexei Popyrin sets up second round against Novak Djokovic, winning all-Aussie clash with Marc Polmans
Sad scenes as Terence Atmane forced to retire, sending Daniil Medvedev through to the second round

image.altText: Greta Gerwig and Margot Robbit look at eachother excitedly.

props.synopsis: Oppenheimer edges out Barbie with wins for best picture and best director, after Margot Robbie and Greta Gerwig are singled out for special honours — as it happened.

title.children: Margot Robbie, Greta Gerwig give surprise victory speech after earlier win snubbed from broadcast — as it happened

image.altText: A profile of former Socceroo Stephen Laybutt in his playing kit smiling

props.synopsis: The body of former Socceroos player Stephen Laybutt is found in bushland by police after he was reported missing in Casuarina.

title.children: Former Socceroos player Stephen Laybutt found dead in northern NSW

image.altText: a man pushes the button on a washing machine that's full of clothes

props.synopsis: Clothes shed microfibres while they are manufactured, worn and disposed of, but especially when they are washed. A single wash load can release several million microfibres — but you can decrease this by changing your technique.

title.children: Laundry is a top source of microplastic pollution — but you can clean your clothes more sustainably

image.altText: A composite image of Emily Blunt, Ashley Madekwe, Colman Domingo and Margot Robbie

props.synopsis: The Critics Choice Awards bring together stars from both television and film, offering up a fashion feast on the red carpet.

title.children: Critics Choice red carpet offers up red roses, golden boots and a really long button-up shirt

image.altText: A very small jellyfish with four tentacles

props.synopsis: As visitor numbers surge on K'gari (Fraser Island) during summer months, so too does the number of potentially deadly stingers in its waters, as authorities reiterate safety messages about marine life.

title.children: Jellyfish stings off K'gari (Fraser Island) put two children and one man in hospital

image.altText: Chris O'Connell pups his fists as he celebrates winning a point during an Australian Open match.

props.synopsis: At one stage during his injury-disrupted career, Chris O'Connell was cleaning boats at a marina to make a living. He now finds himself entrenched inside the top 100 as he looks to make a deep run at the Australian Open.

title.children: How Chris O'Connell wants to show 30 is the new 20 in the tennis world

image.altText: An Australian male tennis player hits a double-fisted backhand at the 2024 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: It might be modest compared to what Novak Djokovic earns, but Dane Sweeny's payday for making the first round of the Australian Open goes a long way when you're ranked 257 in the world.

title.children: Dane Sweeny shared an Airbnb before his Australian Open debut, such is the cost of being a pro tennis player

image.altText: Royal couple at their wedding looking at each other sitting on gold thrones.

props.synopsis: Once described as Asia's most eligible bachelor, Brunei's Prince Abdul Mateen, the son of one of the world’s richest men, ties the knot in a lavish 10-day affair.

title.children: 'Heartbreak' for royal fans as Asia's most eligible prince marries in lavish 10-day celebration

image.altText: A group of people on a picnic rug at a beach with drinks in hand.

props.synopsis: From having picnics at the beach near where Mary grew up, to friends of her late mother getting together to mark the milestone, here's how Australians have celebrated the rise of one of their own.

title.children: In the suburb where Mary grew up, locals celebrate the rise of a queen

image.altText: Uniformed police and detectives outside the Woolworths.

props.synopsis: A Woolworths Metro in the Brisbane suburb of Teneriffe is spray painted with profanities surrounding the Australia Day controversy, with the apartment building above evacuated after a flare was set off.

title.children: 'Boycott Woolies': Brisbane Woolworths vandalised amid Australia Day controversy, apartment evacuated

image.altText: A wrought iron sign reading "warmest welcome from Australia's hottest town".

props.synopsis: In the West Australian town of Marble Bar, Sunday was the first day since December 18 with a temperature high below 43 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Australia's 'hottest town' swelters through almost a month of highs above 43 degrees Celsius

image.altText: Adrian Wells holds a copy of his book while sitting in a garden.

props.synopsis: Adrian Wells aims to ignite a passion for the environment and break down stereotypes that city people might have about farming communities.

title.children: Students need 'all points of view' not 'shouting and yelling' about Murray-Darling Basin, author says

image.altText: Brisbane inner city suburbs rooftops solar panels

props.synopsis: St Vincent de Paul calls for an urgent shake-up of power bills, warning the cost of Australia's clean energy transition is disproportionately falling on poorer customers.

title.children: Charity warns vulnerable households bearing brunt of green energy schemes

image.altText: Director Sofia Coppola, Costume Designer Stacey Battat hold a wedding dress worn by actor Cailee Spaeny who is looking back

props.synopsis: Director Sofia Coppola says Priscilla Presley "goes through moments that every girl goes through as you grow up" in her eponymous new film about Elvis' bride.

title.children: 'I'm sorry she couldn't see it': Sofia Coppola laments Lisa Marie Presley didn't see final film of her mother's story

image.altText: Rod Laver Arena bathed in sunshine with packed stands

props.synopsis: Here's your comprehensive pocket guide on the first grand slam of the season.

title.children: Want to catch all the action from the Australian Open? Here's where to watch and all the Aussie players in main draw

image.altText: A photo taken from above of four people doing a jigsaw puzzle together on a black table

props.synopsis: We take a look at some of the latest research on keeping your brain healthy and reducing the risk of dementia.

title.children: Ways to reduce the risk of dementia and improve brain health that may surprise you

image.altText: A person holds an "I voted" sticker

props.synopsis: The first votes of the 2024 US election season will soon be cast. Here's what you need to know about the process that will answer the question: Who will be up against Joe Biden?

title.children: Americans are about to start voting as the race for the White House gets underway. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Alex de Minaur points up to the sky

props.synopsis: Is it easier to win your home grand slam than any other major? Some stats suggest that top players are more likely to win at home, but it's not as simple as that, Simon Smale writes.

title.children: It's been 48 years since an Australian man won the Australian Open — can de Minaur break that drought?

image.altText: Flames from a bushfire in Bindoon

props.synopsis: One of two emergency bushfires burning north of Perth is downgraded, as firefighters battle several out-of-control blazes north of Perth.

title.children: At least one property destroyed as hundreds of firefighters battle out-of-control blazes north of Perth

image.altText: Young people stand near and in a dilapidated home after the Tongan eruption and tsunami.

props.synopsis: Today marks the second anniversary of the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano's eruption, which hurled a plume of ash and rock almost 60 kilometres into the atmosphere and triggered a tsunami and shock wave. Photographer Leki Lao's images were some of the first to emerge from the devastation.

title.children: When a Tongan volcano erupted two years ago, the kingdom was cut off from the world. These images were some of the first to emerge
